quote: Don't wait for the perfect storm to set sail – launch your ship and adjust the sails as you go. Every day you delay is a day your competitors get ahead.
AI tools are like having a very enthusiastic intern – they'll do exactly what you ask, but you better be crystal clear about what you actually want.
Family business isn't about choosing between family and business – it's about building something so aligned with your values that the two become one treasure map.
Ship early, ship often, ship scared. The market will teach you more in a week than your brain will in a year of planning.
Being a solo developer is like being a one-person pirate crew – you're the captain, the navigator, and the person swabbing the deck. Embrace the chaos.
Don't build what you think people want. Build what you wish existed, then find the people who've been wishing for the same thing.
Every 'overnight success' is really just someone who got really good at failing fast and learning faster. Master the art of productive failure.
Your first thousand lines of code will be terrible. Your first thousand customers will be confused. That's not failure – that's tuition for your real education.
AI won't replace developers, but developers who use AI will replace developers who don't. Learn to dance with the robots.
Working from home with kids is like coding during a very loud, very unpredictable user acceptance test. Embrace the interruptions – they're feature requests from your most important clients.
Stop optimizing for the perfect launch. Start optimizing for the perfect learning loop. Every iteration should make you smarter, not just prettier.
Your side project is not a hobby – it's your research and development department. Treat it with the respect it deserves.
Debug your assumptions before you debug your code. Most bugs live in the space between what you think you built and what you actually built.
Building a family business is like raising kids and growing a garden at the same time – everything needs attention, but not everything needs it right now.
The best AI prompt is like the best code comment – it explains not just what you want, but why you want it and what good looks like.
Revenue is not the scoreboard – it's the fuel. Keep your tank full, but remember you're racing toward impact, not just income.
Every developer needs three skills: the ability to break things, the patience to fix them, and the wisdom to know which is which.
Don't ship features, ship solutions. Don't ship solutions, ship understanding. Don't ship understanding, ship transformation.
Working with family means you can't fire your co-founders, but you also can't quit on them. That constraint breeds the kind of commitment that builds empires.
AI is not magic – it's a very powerful pattern recognition engine. Feed it good patterns, get good results. Feed it garbage, get expensive garbage.
Your minimum viable product should be embarrassingly small but defiantly useful. If you're not a little ashamed of your first version, you waited too long.
Bootstrap like a pirate: take what you can, give nothing back to venture capital, and always keep your treasure map close to your chest.
The best code is not the cleverest code – it's the code that makes the next developer smile instead of swear. Future you will thank present you.
Family meetings are just sprint retrospectives with higher emotional stakes and better snacks. Apply the same rules: be honest, be kind, be focused.
Stop asking AI to write your code and start asking it to explain the code you're about to write. The best AI is a really good rubber duck.
